melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: None
author.description: There is no author associated with this line, as it may be the preamble to the hymn

translation.text: Loving the Lord, one's sins are taken away.

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. This Raag encourages the mind to brush away its selfishness, just like spring-cleaning removes all the cobwebs and creates a fresh start. There are feelings of hope and expectation of a new beginning and the start of a new cycle. However, these emotions are not dependent on the physical change of the season, but are an encouragement of an internal effort to change.

author.author: Guru Arjan Dev
author.description:
Guru Arjan Dev [1563 - 1606] was the fifth Guru of the Sikhs, born at Goindval. He was the youngest of the three sons of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Sikh Guru.

Guru Arjan Dev finished the construction of the Harimandir Sahib, the Golden Temple, and compiled the first Sikh scripture, known as the Adi Granth. Shortly after he became the first martyr of the Sikh religion, which formed a turning point in the development of the faith.

translation.text: Meditating on the Lord, one does not suffer at all.

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. This Raag encourages the mind to brush away its selfishness, just like spring-cleaning removes all the cobwebs and creates a fresh start. There are feelings of hope and expectation of a new beginning and the start of a new cycle. However, these emotions are not dependent on the physical change of the season, but are an encouragement of an internal effort to change.

author.author: Guru Arjan Dev
author.description:

translation.text: Meditating on the Lord of the Universe, all darkness is dispelled.

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. translation.text: Meditating in remembrance on the Lord, the cycle of reincarnation comes to an end. ||1||

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. translation.text: The love of the Lord is springtime for me.

text: ਸੰਤ ਜਨਾ ਸਿਉ ਸਦਾ ਸੰਗੁ ॥੧॥ ਰਹਾਉ ॥

translation.text: I am always with the humble Saints. ||1||Pause||

transliteration.text: sant janā siu sadā sang .1. rahāu .

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. This Raag encourages the mind to brush away its selfishness, just like spring-cleaning removes all the cobwebs and creates a fresh start. There are feelings of hope and expectation of a new beginning and the start of a new cycle. However, these emotions are not dependent on the physical change of the season, but are an encouragement of an internal effort to change.

translation.text: The Saints have shared the Teachings with me.

text: ਜਹ ਗੋਬਿੰਦ ਭਗਤੁ ਸੋ ਧੰਨਿ ਦੇਸੁ ॥

translation.text: Blessed is that country where the devotees of the Lord of the Universe dwell.

transliteration.text: jah gōbind bhagat sō dhann dēs .

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. This Raag encourages the mind to brush away its selfishness, just like spring-cleaning removes all the cobwebs and creates a fresh start. translation.text: But that place where the Lord's devotees are not, is wilderness.

translation.text: By Guru's Grace, realize the Lord in each and every heart. ||2||

text: ਮਨ ਪਾਪ ਕਰਤ ਤੂ ਸਦਾ ਸੰਗੁ ॥

translation.text: O mortal, you must always restrain yourself from committing sins.

transliteration.text: man pāp karat tū sadā sang .

text: ਤੇਰਿਆ ਸੰਤ ਜਨਾ ਕੀ ਬਾਛਉ ਧੂਰਿ ॥

translation.text: I yearn for the dust of the feet of Your Saints.

transliteration.text: tēriā sant janā kī bāshau dhūr .
